meanings.def: to hit somebody/something with your foot
examples: Stop kicking—it hurts!
kick somebody/something She was punched and kicked by her attackers.
kick somebody/something + adv./prep./adj. The boys were kicking a ball around in the yard.
Vandals had kicked the door down.
She had to kick the door open because her hands were full.
kick + adv./prep. She kicked at the loose pebbles by the roadside.
Don't kick the ball too hard.
He was sent off for deliberately kicking an Italian player.
They threw him to the ground and kicked him hard in the stomach.
Marcia gently kicked the horse again to make it trot.
She could feel the baby kicking against her stomach wall.
She kicked at the loose pebbles by the roadside.
Abe roared and kicked over a table.
She kicked me on the knee.
Suddenly the far door was kicked open.
He got up angrily and kicked the chair over.

meanings.def: to move your legs as if you were kicking something
examples: The child was dragged away, kicking and screaming.
kick something The dancers kicked their legs in the air.
He rolled over in the sand, kicking wildly.
I tried to dive back under, kicking with my legs.
I was carried upstairs, arms waving and legs kicking.
The little boy was now lying on his back kicking his legs in the air.

meanings.def: to be annoyed with yourself because you have done something stupid, missed an opportunity, etc.
examples: He'll kick himself when he finds out he could have had the job.
I could kick myself for being so stupid.
I mentally kicked myself for missing such an opportunity.

meanings.def: to score points by kicking the ball
examples: to kick a penalty/goal
He kicked 23 points, ensuring victory for New Zealand.

meanings.def: to stop doing something harmful that you have done for a long time
examples: He had been smoking for 15 years and wanted to kick the habit.
to kick the drug/booze

meanings.def: very active, healthy or popular
examples: My mother is still alive and kicking.

meanings.def: to hit somebody/something very hard
examples: He was a dirty player and loved to kick hell out of the opposition.

meanings.def: to act in a way that is aggressive or full of energy
to succeed or win in an impressive way
to punish or defeat somebody
to die
to delay dealing with a problem
examples: This is another attempt to kick the can down the road and leave it to the next generation.

meanings.def: to have nothing to do while you are waiting for somebody/something
examples: We were kicking our heels, waiting for some customers.

meanings.def: if you drag somebody kicking and screaming to do something, they only do it with great protests because they don't really want to do it at all
examples: The president had to be dragged kicking and screaming to the signing ceremony.

meanings.def: to treat somebody badly or fail to give them help when they need it
to reject something or treat it as not important; to stop dealing with a problem
examples: He tends to deal with disputes by kicking them into the long grass.

meanings.def: to start to behave badly and refuse to accept any discipline or control
to test the quality of something to see whether it is suitable for you before you buy it
to complain loudly about something
examples: They’ll usually give you your money back if you threaten to kick up a stink.

meanings.def: to be relaxed and enjoy yourself
to move somebody to a job that seems to be more important but that actually has less power or influence
to continue to hurt somebody when they are already defeated, etc.

examples: My mother is still alive and kicking.

idioms.idiom: beat/kick (the) hell out of somebody/something | knock hell out of somebody/something
examples: He was a dirty player and loved to kick hell out of the opposition.

idioms.def: to act in a way that is aggressive or full of energy
to delay dealing with a problem
examples: This is another attempt to kick the can down the road and leave it to the next generation.

idioms.def: to have nothing to do while you are waiting for somebody/something
examples: We were kicking our heels, waiting for some customers.

idioms.def: if you drag somebody kicking and screaming to do something, they only do it with great protests because they don't really want to do it at all
examples: The president had to be dragged kicking and screaming to the signing ceremony.

idioms.def: to treat somebody badly or fail to give them help when they need it

idioms.idiom: kick something into the long grass/into touch
idioms.def: to reject something or treat it as not important; to stop dealing with a problem
examples: He tends to deal with disputes by kicking them into the long grass.

idioms.def: to start to behave badly and refuse to accept any discipline or control
to test the quality of something to see whether it is suitable for you before you buy it

idioms.idiom: kick up a fuss, stink, etc.
examples: They’ll usually give you your money back if you threaten to kick up a stink.

idioms.def: to be relaxed and enjoy yourself
to move somebody to a job that seems to be more important but that actually has less power or influence
to continue to hurt somebody when they are already defeated, etc.

meanings.def: a movement with the foot or the leg, usually to hit something with the foot
examples: the first kick of the game
He barely got a kick of the ball the whole match.
She gave him a kick on the shin.
If the door won't open, give it a kick.
He aimed a kick at the dog.
He had received a painful kick on the knee.
I got a kick in the stomach and doubled over in pain.
He received a number of kicks to his head as he lay on the ground.
Olivia leapt forward with a high karate kick.
Roy landed a kick to the man's head.
an energetic performer using dance routines and high kicks

meanings.def: a strong feeling of excitement and pleasure
examples: I get a kick out of driving fast cars.
He gets his kicks from hurting other people.
for kicks What do you do for kicks?
He gets his kicks from skiing.
It gave the youngsters a kick to see their own play on television.
They don't really want the things they steal. They just do it for kicks.

meanings.def: the strong effect that a drug or an alcoholic drink has
examples: This drink has quite a kick.

meanings.def: a soft shoe that you wear for sports or as informal clothing
examples: The actor wore denim, a simple tee and a nice pair of kicks.

meanings.def: if you think somebody needs a kick in the pants or a kick up the backside you think they need to be strongly encouraged to do something or behave better
something that hurts somebody/something emotionally; a great disappointment
examples: The job losses are a kick in the teeth for the union.

idioms.idiom: a kick in the pants/up the backside
idioms.def: if you think somebody needs a kick in the pants or a kick up the backside you think they need to be strongly encouraged to do something or behave better
something that hurts somebody/something emotionally; a great disappointment
examples: The job losses are a kick in the teeth for the union.
